title: 110_hr883
content: The Act is titled the "Oglala Sioux Tribe Angostura Irrigation Project Modernization and Development Act". It includes findings related to the project. The Angostura Unit is part of the Pick-Sloan program approved by Congress in 1944 to promote economic development, provide irrigation, and protect areas from Missouri River floods. It irrigates around 12,218 acres of farmland in South Dakota. The Angostura Unit in South Dakota provides economic benefits through irrigation and recreation, with annual benefits totaling $3,410,000 and $7,100,000 respectively. It impounds the Cheyenne River and is located near the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, which faces high rates of unemployment and poverty, highlighting the need for economic development in the area. The Angostura Unit in South Dakota provides economic benefits through irrigation and recreation, with annual benefits totaling $3,410,000 and $7,100,000 respectively. There is a need for economic development on the Reservation, and modernization of the irrigation facilities at the Angostura Unit could enhance national economic development benefits and improve water efficiency and environmental restoration on the Reservation. Additionally, establishing a trust fund for the Oglala Sioux tribe could produce economic development benefits for the Reservation. The Reservation aims to provide benefits similar to the Angostura Unit and resources for the restoration of the Cheyenne River corridor. The Reservation aims to provide benefits similar to the Angostura Unit and resources for the restoration of the Cheyenne River corridor. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, key definitions include the Angostura Unit, Fund, Pick-Sloan program, Plan, Reservation, and Secretary. These terms clarify various aspects of the legislation related to the Oglala Sioux Tribe and the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, while "Tribe" specifically means the Oglala Sioux Tribe of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. The "Tribal Council" is defined as the governing body of the Tribe. SEC. 4. MODERNIZATION. The Secretary will modernize and improve facilities at the Angostura Unit as described in the Improved Efficiencies Alternative. The cost will be nonreimbursable. Water saved will be delivered to the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation for fish and wildlife purposes and environmental restoration. Authorization of $4,660,000 for wildlife and environmental restoration on the Reservation. SEC. 5. DEVELOPMENT. The Oglala Sioux Tribal Development Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States with an initial deposit of $92,500,000 from the General Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury will invest the fund to meet current withdrawals. The Secretary of the Treasury will invest the amounts deposited in interest-bearing obligations of the United States and deposit the resulting interest into the Fund. On October 1st of each year, the Secretary will transfer the aggregate amount of interest deposited into the Fund for the fiscal year to be used accordingly. The Secretary of the Interior will use transferred amounts for payments to the Tribe as requested, following tribal resolution and adoption of a plan. The Tribe must use payments for projects and programs outlined in a development plan prepared within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Treasury Secretary cannot transfer or withdraw deposited amounts, except as specified. The Tribe must use payments for economic development, infrastructure development, and educational, health, recreational, and social welfare objectives. The Tribal Council must make the plan available for review and comment by the members of the Tribe before it becomes final. The Tribal Council may revise the plan annually, allowing members of the Tribe to review and comment. Consultation with the Secretary and the Secretary of Health and Human Services is required in preparing and revising the plan. An audit is also necessary. The Tribe's activities under the plan will be audited annually as part of a single-agency audit required by the Office of Management and Budget circular A-133. Auditors will determine if funds received were properly expended. The Tribe's activities under the plan will be audited annually to ensure proper expenditure of funds. The audit findings will be included in the Tribal Council proceedings. No per capita payments are allowed. No per capita payments allowed under the Act, Tribe's eligibility for programs and services protected, appropriations authorized for administrative expenses, and disclaimer of effects on Tribe's rights under the Treaty. The Tribe's rights under the Treaty of Fort Laramie of 1851 and 1868, as well as their reserved water rights under Winters v. United States, are protected.
